text:
Hi, I’m having some trouble with uploading files via `hs upload filemanager [src] [dest]`. I get the error message “[ERROR] The path “filemanager” is not a path to a file or folder”

FYI, I’m running the command where the config yml is, and src is set to [project name]/[assets folder] [target folder name]
Looks like “upload” and “filemanager” are in the wrong order if you’re trying to upload to the file manager. Should be `hs upload filemanager`.
Yeah, exactly.
Was told this may be a better place to ask this question.
<@U7SL518D6>, feel like you would have an answer for that
I'm also not sure this is the best place, or where this would be.
I know nothing about dnd areas lol
i suggested here
figured this is a local dev thing, right?
blame me, decker!
type type type
aren't dnd areas like parts of template that a user can add in an image and a rich text and like move it around?
but dont you add it via local development?
I thought it was a hubl tag.. so I just figured anyone could do it?
<https://designers.HubSpot.com/tutorials/creating-a-drag-and-drop-area>
ps — i am totally out of the loop on dnd
yeah me too.

So to take a stab at this, <@UNR0VMXRA> what are you trying to accomplish by playing a DND area into a blog.. are you trying to add it to a blog post so a user can edit a blog post a little easier?  what is the end result you are trying to accomplish
<https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/archives/CDU990ECW/p1583504798034400?thread_ts=1583473549.033600&cid=CDU990ECW>

Technically <#CDU990ECW|drag-n-drop-pages>  is probably better. That said it requires thought around the content editor experience, and back-end work to make it possible.

Here’s a similar question that Katie Tade, and Jess Scott responded to:
<https://HubSpotdev.slack.com/archives/CDU990ECW/p1583473549033600>
this guy with his useful info
sorry
The real answer is going to be because landing pages and website pages use a different API and are different object than a blog listing or blog post
So when something is made for website /landing pages, it isn't made for all page types
<@U25PYL3Q8> More like just trying to provide the same flexibility to content creators that manage blog sites as the ones who manage regular website pages
no need to apologize!!!!!
<@UBT0AHWLD> Good to know, yeah guess that makes sense.
yeah, that isnt there, yet
You can put custom modules into your template
So it's not super unreasonable to expect that dnd areas will eventually make their way to blog templates, right?
`unreasonable`
It isn't super unreasonable, I'm sure if you reached out to Jess Scot that answered that original question, you might be able to get on the beta when it happens
have to admit, things are happening fast in HubSpot land.  might be sooner than you think.
and def add to the ideas forumn

SO, You can put custom modules into a blog template. And, if your content managers and your developers are crafty enough you can technically insert that custom module INTO a blog post so that it is "inside" the post.
great, suspected as much, was already pleasantly surprised with all the new functionality with HubL HTML templates supporting dnd areas from like months ago
Yeah that's fine with us, less worried about custom modules inside actual posts and more of wanting them on like the listing template
alongside native blog content, not necessarily nested
sounds like we can still insert custom modules into blog templates, just no dnd areas yet
ps, i still think this was the correct channel
heh, well this is where i got responses immediately fwiw so i'd agree
thanks all

I've done this by creating a custom module, lets call this one a photo gallery. Basicaly a slide show or gallery. Now you would normally have to place that somewhere lower or higher on the page.  If you have your content creators use a piece of html in their blog post (example: `<h2>[gallery]</h2>` ) then you could take the content and do a replace on in your template inside an if statement if the gallery was used in the blog post, then use javascript to replace it
I would have asked in hubl
lol
AHAHAHHAHA
classic, now you have n+1 channels
I'm not in that channel that's why it didn't get answered lol
it is not restricted to local development. You could add these tags using coded templates in the design manager

you are correct, it doesn’t require using the CLI.

It does however require coded templates, It is not supported in the old design manager drag and drop templates
Damnit, jon
Problem here is that you do not get the functionality that the 'Blog content' module has to offer right?
